transcript.content: Kings Of Leon, California Waiting. Steve, the public have been waiting for us to return.
I bet that was a joy.

They had Camfield and us, without Karl, the week before, but it's er, been a while since we've all been together. I'm Ricky Gervais, with me is Steve Merchant, and over there, with his little sunburnty baldy head, little Karl Pilkington.
Yep. Tha-that wasn't Steve slapping my head then, by the way.
No, that was just him clapping, like Steve Wright in the afternoon...
...cos he's, he's so....it is a great show.
He's so pleased that we're a posse, and we're all back together. That's three holidays Karl's had this year. Last year.
I'd love to have three holidays. You've got to start putting the work in...
No, I had two holidays, though.
No, you had three holidays! You went away with, er, Suzanne and her parents.

It does count. If you book..if you book two weeks off the firm, and you go away, and you go "How was your holiday go?" "Well, it didn't really count, it wasn't a really good holiday. Can I have them days back please?" You.....oh. My new year's resolution is to be nicer to you. But...
Well done, you've already broken that.

...talk sense. No, but talk sense. Talk sense. You've had three holidays this year, and I'm just saying. You-you're in your thirties now, and thirties is when you should really be putting the work in...
...to reap the benefits in your forties, fifties, sixties, seventies, eighties, nineties and a hundred.
Karl, what's your new year resolution? What about 'think before you speak'?
See, I'm allowed to laugh. I'm allowed to laugh at things other people say, Karl. That one...
That is a good suggestion! How was your holiday, Karl?
But that, I don't see...on the kind of, on the ratio of good to bad in Karl's mind, that might be amazing...
...'cause we never hear him singing the praises of anything.
I tell you what, can we have a, you know, cracking little tune, then come back and hear about Karl's holiday?
Joy Division - Love Will Tear Us Apart

Love Will Tear Us Apart, by Joy Division. Now, I can't put my finger on it, but that doesn't sound like the original. And it's off a compilation. It sounded a bit fast, I think the vocal's slightly different. If anyone can, you know, put me out my misery, I think it might have been a session of the time, or something.
Karl, here's a little new year resolution for you, another one. Maybe when we ask you to get a song, get the er, original single version...
It does seem different, doesn't it?

Maybe we just remember it wrongly. But anyway, that's XFM for you. 104.9. I'm Ricky Gervais, with me Steve Merchant; Karl Pilkington. Karl, you went to Lanzarote. People said "don't go to Lanzarote", they told you it was Lanze-grotty, they told you, were they right or wrong?
Yeah, it's a bit ropey, yeah.
Just er....nowt there. If it wasn't for the...for the volcano they had, they'd be knackered.
That's their...that's their big draw is it?
That's, that's it basically. That's all they've got going for them.
When you landed, was it really hot, did you..initally were you quite excited, you were thinking "this is okay"?
Yeah it was warm, it's, you know, can't complain about the weather, the weather was alright.
You know what I mean? That's what I went for, but it'd be nice if...if there just was something else.
What did you do all day then? Did you read your Rich Hall book?
Err, no, I didn't read that. I read that book, do you know that book that I bought and all the chapters were messed up?
I bought a better version of that.
Did it make more sense in order?
Yeah, a lot easier to follow.
And then we went and had a look at the volcanoes and that, they've got thirty six of them to look at.
How many did you look at before you realised you've, you know, pretty much you've seen one volcano you've seen them all?
Really? And then when you got to the eighth you thought "Now I know what this is going to be, Suzanne. This is going to be, like, a mountain with a hole in the top."
But it happened years ago as well, it's like, just keep a couple, fill the rest in. Tidy it up.
"Can I have four million tonnes of concrete, please?"
Yeah, what...yeah...what do you mean, fill 'em in? Do you know what a volcano is?
Just a hole innit, that's happened.
Well it's more than a hole, it's more a portal to the magma in the center of the earth.
Back in 1730, it happened, and they still haven't sorted it out.
Well when you say "it happened", volcanoes were made a lot longer ago...
But the one that did Lanzarote in.
What do you suggest? How can they fill it in, it's joined, it's all joined. Under...
No, but what I'm saying is...
...big plates of the Earth are all joined, all the magma's joined.

...it was a disaster, wasn't it? With the, with the Trade Center thing. That happened, they cleaned it up, sorted it out, they've moved on. That's what I'm saying. Whereas Lanzarote have just gone "leave it". It happened back in 1730.
No, you misunderstand me. How in the name of God can you fill in a volcano, you ignorant twit?
No, but it's not just the holes, they've actually left the lava everywhere. That's what I mean. It's not just the big holes, there's lava everywhere.
But...it's molten rock. They can't just pick it up, like they're...like a carpet.
Put it in the holes, the holes are there ready, just push it all in.
What, erm, what exactly is there then? Is it just a kind of moon-like kind of surround with just, kind of dust and rocks?
That's exact....you see, I was there when the Mars thing all went wrong.
I would have just sent a camera crew there.
Filmed a bit of that, right, say "here we are, this is it. Ignore the little coffee shop in the background. This is Mars." 'Cause that's what it's like, just loads of dust...
Just like Mars! So is there any..what's the best bit about the holiday? Come on, pretend you're Judith Chalmers.
I have been doing. I would have done all that. I would have said that. Don't bother.
I mean the hotel was good.
S'alright. Just, you know, clean. That's all you want, innit?

See, that's not quite what Judith Chalmers does, she doesn't go "What's the hotel like? Alright, clean innit...alright". What was it like? Was it, what was it, three star? Four star? Did it have a swimming pool?
Yeah, it had a swimming pool and that.
Erm, yeah. It was good. You know, I think it was one of the better ones on the island.
Wasn't really any. There was a bar, there was some bands playing.
Er, not very good. Erm....food. Food got a bit boring.
It was always the same food every night, but they sort of themed it and made out as if it was different, so like, on Mexican night it'd be chicken with a nacho on it.
And Chinese night it'd be chicken with a little prawn cracker on it and stuff.
Erm, that's just me turning on my phone, 'cause I want to read to you a text...
...that I got from Karl. I think you sort of sum up the holiday in..in this text, don't you? Can you remember it?
Let's have a look, let's have a little look...
Incidentally, what did Suzanne, your girlfriend, make of it?
Similar view to you? That they should fill in the er, the holes?

Yeah, it's just that thing you see, I went on a coach trip, right? And you go and see the volcanoes. Like I say, there's thirty six of them, which, you know, how many do you need? And er, when we're on the coach going round all these volcanoes, the fella on the front's going "And er, look out your left window at the moment, there's a..there's a volcano. And er, if you quickly look out the right hand side there, there's another one, and on the left..." and it's just like, alright, we've seen it!
Do you know what I mean?
And that, that tr-I mean we'll talk about that trip...

Right, this is the text I got, from Karl, right? "Alright? Been up to a volcano. Been in some dead artist's house who built his house in the lava. They said they would show me science with volcanoes, but all they did was chuck some water in a..in a hole and it shot up in the air. No dwarves in the canteen. No Scousers here, but there is a Swede woman with a big head. She looks effing gormless with a cap on."
Alright? So, a little reference there to...
What's that mean, do you mean Swedish?
Or she looked like a vegetable?
No a..a Swedish woman. But they've all got sort of..quite big built, aren't they?

I sent..I sent him a text: "Oh well, it's just good to be on holiday 'cause, you know, I'm working". He sent back, "So am I. Just been watching Sky News. There is a school for monkeys who want to get a band together".
Is that Monkey News for later?
Oh My Corazon, by Tim Burgess. I can't get enough of that, I love that chorus.
On XFM 104.9. Ricky Gervais, Steve Merchant and little Karl Pilkington. But, it was a nice holiday?
Yeah, it's alright, it's just, er, I went there to relax and that-
-did a little bit of that. Er, trying to think of some new, you know, features and stuff.
Well, not really three, more like two.
It's all one, one big work thing to me and Steve.
Just two. Two holidays, innit? Work hard, you need the holidays. Er, so, yeah, the things that annoyed me was, like, you get bored sat round the pool after a couple of days. I'd read my book-
-er, you know, there wasn't much going on on the-
There weren't many crabs to throw sand at, was there?

No crabs or anything, they wouldn't bother with Lanzarote, right? So er, decided to go on a little, a little trip. That's when I saw the volcanoes and that, thirty six of 'em. Er, so, we go on the trip, and the thing that annoys me, it does happen every holiday that you go on, if you go on a sort of package thing-
-they have these trips, right? And you pay about forty-odd quid, and they give you some wine, to sort of make you feel like you're getting your money's worth. But, er-
How many of these trips have you been on then?
Ohh, more holidays than I've had. Go on.
So anyway, you're on the, on the coach, right? And they take you, for the volcanoes they took us in the middle of nowhere-

It's, it-like I say, it's like Mars, but with holes in the ground, right? And er, they sort of drop you off, and they go "Right everybody, er, see you back here in an hour. Er, there's loads of volcanoes for you to look at. Er, and a coffee shop over there". And you know for a fact, right, you don't need an hour there. You could just say "Well, just keep the engine running because I'll have a look in this hole, we'll get back on, give us five minutes".
You don't need an hour. But you know that they've got something going on-
-definitely, yeah. Yeah, they go there, they get everyone to have an ice cream and a coffee, they, you know, sit down and have a fag talking to the bloke. Yeah, and it's like, yeah, cousins. Yeah.
How much was the coffee? Was it extortionately priced?
Probably about, probably about three, er...well it's Euros so I think it was about 3.50.
Which is, I dunno, what, that's about two and a half quid innit, or something?

Yeah, they stitched you up. Well I remember we were on a-it was a family trip to France once, we went to Paris. We got the coach, coming back from Paris to one of the ferries, one of the ports, Calais or wherever it was. Coach trip, that's quite a long coach trip, and at one point we were thinking "this is odd, we're on the motorway, we're making good progress". Suddenly, we came off the motorway, we must have gone, like, forty minutes out of our way, ended up in this street, completely empty, little French town. And er, pull up outside this, what appears to be a restaurant, and a guy jumps on dressed as a, like a Butlins redcoat. He's French, but he's putting on a kind of English accent. He goes "'Ello, er, thank you very much. Top of the morning, good morning, hello. Erm, come in, we've got food, drink, eh? Go upstairs, we've got rooms if you want to have a rest, eh, or play around. No? It's up to you". And er, we all had to funnel off this thing into this restaurant, and this one family went "Well we don't want to go in the restaurant, we've brought sandwiches, we just want to get to the port, we're not interested". And they said "Well you've got to come in the restaurant". They went "well we don't want to come in the restaurant". So the guy said "well I'll have to lock you in the coach". So this family were locked in the coach while we all traipsed off in. I could just look-I looked back and just saw this kid with his face pressed up against the glass.
"Take me with you. I want to go in the restaurant". They were just stuck in there, I mean, absolutely livid, as you would be.
But we went inside and it was extraordinary, 'cause initially you had to pass through a souvenir shop-

And he'd just, he'd obviously-it was catered entirely to English tourists. So there was like, pictures of the Queen and Prince Charles on the wall. It was done out in a kind of mock Tudor style. It's absolutely extraordinary, I, it was just-it was almost so bizarre, 'cause it's so out of the way. Did it, did that come before the coach, er scam, or did the coach guy knows it, is it a brother of his? I don't know how those things come about, but erm-
But I know, it is, it is-yeah.
But is that going on in this country?

Yeah there's er, yeah I'm sure people say "Look, if you bring thirty people to this restaurant, I'll see you're alright". But it would, wouldn't it, you know, if you've got your favourites. Cos the coach driver's pretty much God on those things. Those people don't know where they're going anyway.
Yeah, but at least here there's other stuff around. You don't really get that 'in the middle of nowhere' situation in this country.

Well not really. Not if you're going from er, London to Manchester, you could stop off anywhere. They don't know where they are. You know, there's places with nothing to do or see. It's that-what are those attractions, they're all-there's loads of them in America, but there's a few here like, you know, Sheep World. And er, you know, you go out to Gloucester and there's a town and it's got the biggest cotton reel in the world. And that's it, there's a tourist shop, a big cotton reel and some bloke at the gate going "It's a quid to see it, there it is. Alright?"
I went to erm, I know it's quite a big-I went to a shire horse centre once-
-but when did shire horses become so, so popular that they got their own theme parks?
Well there's, I think-I think there's a museum for everything.
I don't think you could think of summat that didn't have a museum in Britain. 'Cause obviously museums start off sometimes by fans-
But this is it, do people keep coming round, going "I hear you've got a shire horse, I'd love to see it".
"Well I can't, people come all the time to see my shire horse-"
"You should get another one 'cause I'd pay double".
"I'd pay good money to see your shire horses".
Shire horses?! Have you seen them? They don't do anything, they're not like monkeys!
Just grand, elegant creatures. But you look at them in a picture or look at them in real life, pretty much the same thing. They're not doing anything.
If they-if they could train a shire horse to swing on a rope and masturbate-
There's a museum in Italy, when we went there a couple of years back, Suzanne had a, like, one of those little guide things. Museum there just for spaghetti.
Well I mean, open a restaurant.
Was it interesting spaghetti? Spaghetti in different shapes?
Dunno. Dunno, didn't go, I went to see a big hole in the ground.
Well er, but out of ten then? Erm, what would you give it out of ten, all in all? Food...food, location, relaxation, you know, enjoyment.
Next week, where are you going next week? You're not on holiday next week?
No. Going away with Suzanne's mam and dad again. This year-
Play a record. You've got to put some work in, you're in your thirties now. You've got to knuckle down.
Turin Brakes, Mind Over Money. XFM 104.9. I'm Ricky Gervais, Stephen Merchant, little Karl Pilkington.
Yeah. Couple of emails. People have erm, have visited various er, tourist attractions-
Er, let me see, who's this from? Er, not quite sure, but thanks very much indeed for it. Er, there's a link here, it's apparently in Devon, Barometer World.
Erm, the world of barometers, it was established in 1979. And, er-
By one bloke who had a lot, and thought "I can charge a quid for this". Definitely.
Out of his own house, probably. Converted back scuttle.
That's not, that's not a euphemism for a sexual act. Erm-
But looking at the webpage here Rick, there's a beautiful barometer being held by a beautiful lady.
Definitely. "Come on Kathy". "Dad, no!" "Come on, get-undo your top a little bit". "Dad!" Definitely made to do that.
Yeah. That slight look of 'I hope no-one I know sees this'-
Yeah that's available, if you want to check that out - www.barometerworld.com. That's on the, er-
Now...barometers. Do-well one, do they work?
Well, everything. But I think that's what it's based on, isn't it. Sort of low and high pressure, so it's gonna rain, it's not gonna rain.
Or, gonna be windy or, but I wonder how accurate they are.
I think in the days before, erm, satellite sort of, er, weather surveillance systems, probably essential.
As essential as hanging some seaweed out by the back door?
I think it's probably similar. I think it's the same one as holding a needle and thread over a pregnant woman. "If it goes clockwise it be a boy".
The thing about a barometer is, how, erm, how far into the future can it predict?
'Cause if it's a case of, you may as well stick your head out the window to see if it's raining-
Exactly, this barometer goes, it goes "Ooh, it's gonna be windy and rainy". "When?" Barometer goes, "Soonish?".
"Can't say but it will, it will-within seven days".
"I don't want to be specific 'cause you'll have me".
"I mean, I'm just a barometer, I'm not really, a weatherperson".
What's in there, what's happening in there? What chemicals are being affected, how does it work, I have no idea?
I don't know, I assume it's probably something-
Wait a minute, let me email Barometer World.
What could it be? It could be mercury that's based on a sort of temperature that goes up the...oh no it's not temperature, is it, barometer? It's pressure.
So er, it's probably just very fine, it's like a fine, very, very fine needle, isn't it?
This is almost as embarrassing as last time we were on, we couldn't figure out what the name of the leader of China was. Was it the king of China?
Oh, this is where we were trying to imagine what it would be like if all the Chinese people, at once, jumped up and down-

An enormous tidal wave. But if you do know what the name of the leader of China is, we don't mean the name of the particular person in charge, but if it's the king of China, the emperor of China? The chancellor of China?
It used to be an emperor didn't it? Oh no, that was Japan.

Yeah, this is it, I don't what's the big guy in charge. Is he still the chairman, I know there was Chairman Mao, was in power, I think he was just the chairman though. I think he just governed all the big meetings.
Head Chinaman. The major Chinaman. The top Chinaman.
We-do you know what, we're going to be honest here, we know so little about China.
We know so little about China, it's embarrassing.
But if you've got any interesting facts about China, then er, email in. [email protected] Also, I imagine, the email address to use if you're going to take part in this week's Rockbusters.
I did read an interesting fact. Erm, researched it, I'm doing a show called Politics and I was researching, and there's a thing about, erm-

-about sweatshops. Yeah, no, no, no. Sweatshops, erm, like...Nike, er, these facts, right? And erm, er, there's these people get, like, a few cents an hour, and the CEO, I forget his name, for a Chinese woman to earn his 5.2 billion, she'd have to work, erm, eight hours a day, seven days a week for ten thousand years. But Steve, they don't.
They don't. They obviously don't wanna-
Ian Dury and The Blockheads - Hit Me With Your Rhythm Stick
Ian Dury and The Blockheads, Hit Me With Your Rhythm Stick.
Rick, are you likely to be going to, er, Cumbria on your, erm, standup tour?
It's just that you might want to visit the Cumberland Pencil Museum. Erm, that's a journey through the history of pencil making.
Yeah, I just used one then.
Do you have any idea how that was made?
Oh, incidentally it's the Premier of China. The Premier.
Premier. Premier. Oh right, yeah, oh yeah. Sure. I remember now.

Last, er-when you were away, erm, Karl, we worked out, if, erm, if there's one in ten people are sort of like, gay in some way, er, with a billion Chinese people, there's a hundred thousand little erm, little gay, lesbian Chinese fellas of some sort. What do you think of that?
Well, if, I think some sort of form of, erm, gayocity, whatever it's called, er is sort of like one in ten. Right?
One in ten people are gay, apparently.
That does seem a bit high though, doesn't it?
I thought it was, I thought it was lower than that.
What, you mean more than that?
I don't think so. I think that's of any sort of nature, anything-
But what time did they do the survey on the streets as well? 'Cause you know how they go out late, so if they're doing the survey sort of around lunchtime, forget it, they're not going to get any.
You know what I mean? They're all asleep.
But if they're out at, say, one in the morning.
Well, the thing is, you know Karl's favourite song, The Killing Of Georgie?
A little fella-A little gay fella goes out and er, he gets, erm, beaten up and that. Karl went "Yeah, but would it have happened if he'd been going out at a decent time?"
But clearly in the lyric it says "Georgie left the theatre before the final curtain fell".
Now, theatres finish about half ten.
So, even giving him half an hour, I reckon it was only about eleven o'clock. So, you're talking rubbish there.
Are you sure that wasn't his curtains in his flat, and he's closing them before he goes out?
No, he was at the theatre. But I tell you what, I just realised summat. Whereas maybe most people were going home after the theatre, he was just going out.
That theatre to him is like a matinee-
-innit? He's off out clubbing, isn't he? He's off down, he's gonna get some amyl, he's gonna get a couple of buttplugs and he's gonna-he's not even gonna start dancing til midnight, is he?
Have-have any of us ever met any gay people?
It's just, I mean, our view of them is, I don't know, erm....email in if you've met a gay person.
Tell us where we er, where we're going wrong.
Yeah. "Have any of us ever met a gay person!"
I mean, the way we talk about them is just like, have we ever met Chinese people?
I've seen them, I've seen them out there wandering the streets. I don't know if I've ever-
Now here, now here's the irony. I definitely know, and have met, more little gay fellas than little Chinese fellas.
Have you ever made any little Chinese friends?
No, there was this girl at school who was Chinese but she was kind of inscrutable. Couldn't get close to her, she was sort of mysterious.
Right then, there is where I, er, give you a little cryptic clue and some initials, and it sort of makes up a band or an artist and that.
"Sort of" being the operative phrase there.
See how he reads this clue.
This is gonna sound like Oscar Wilde
Right. Will you leave the entrance to my garden alone?
Will you leave the entrance to my garden alone?
Are we back on the gay thing or is this-this is the clue?
That's the clue. Clue for Rockbusters number one. Just leave the entrance to my garden alone, will you?
Right, that doesn't count, 'cause I know what it is.
And what was-what were the initials?
Right. Yeah. But you've got to pronounce the artist correctly. I'll pronounce the artist, 'cause I know what it is.
No, I know, when the artist comes, I'll pronounce the artist.
Right, can we just focus please, on the quiz? Go. What was the clue again? Give it again.
Will you leave the entrance to my garden alone? Stop messing with it. Alright? GG.
Er, don't phone but you can send a message on my mobile if you want. Right?
That's T. Another little, little easy one. And er, the last one. We were sharing out the male sheep-
Right that one doesn't count either
I know what that is, I know what that is.
I don't care, we'll come to that later.
And number three, we were sharing out the male sheep, and I think I got the best one. Right? DG.

Yeah. So quickly again. Will you leave the entrance to my garden alone? Stop messing about with it. Right? GG. Don't phone but you can send us a message on my mobile if you want. Right? That was T. And the last one, we were sharing out the male sheep and I got the best one, so that's good. Right? DG.
Alright. [email protected], have we got any prizes?
Er, you want to have a look?
Well don't worry about it, just-
Don't worry about it, have we got any prizes?
Look, the clues are rubbish. The clues don't work, the show-I mean, this is pathetic. Play a record.
That's what it should be called, 'And The Clues Don't Work'!
Blur, Out Of Time, on XFM. Well we're not out of time, we've still got an hour left boys.

Brilliant. Lot of emails, obviously, about the Chinese. People as fascinated as we are. I don't want to discuss it, you know, interminably, Rick, 'cause there's so much to say and we've said so much of it in the past. Got a couple of emails, in fact Karl, I think you told us this information, remind me of it again? If all the Chinese people in the world were-
Were in a line and that, 'cause there's loads of them you'd never get to the end of it.
No, if all the Chinese people formed a line and started walking out of China, you'd never get to the end of it.
-they'd be having babies, erm, you know what I mean? Still. It'd be adding to it all the time, wouldn't you?
But would they be-would they be walking and shagging, and having babies as they're walking out?
I'd love to see someone organise that. Maybe the Record Breakers team.
I tell you what, I'd love to see Ross McWhirter, or Norris, whoever's-who is it? Who's the one that's alive?
Norris, right. I'd love to see him co-ordinate that.
One point two billion little Chinese fellas, boy, girl, boy, girl, boy, girl.
Yeah. And where are they walking out of China? Which exit are they taking?
-it's the, I think it's the er, gate nine slip road of the M43-
-to St. Petersburg. Right? And they go "And walking. And shagging".
'Cause some presumably are dying as they're leaving.
No, but they live to a hundred and twenty.
-so, well, we know Karl's theory on that. Do you want to tell new listeners your theory about-
-when these Chinese people get the records for oldest people in the world. Come on! What's your theory, Karl?Karl:Leave it.

-that's all. 'Cause a lot of them don't age that well. Some of them do, a lot of them don't. And they always look older than they are. I read the other day, right, do you the one who's the oldest woman in the world? Right, Chinese woman? Erm, the way she did it, it was-
She didn't die. That was-that was the secret. What she did, she got up every day and didn't die.
No, no, she er, she was, like, awake and that and then she'd have two days just sleeping.
So she wasn't really that old.
Well she'd only sort of lived half of her life, in a way-
-two thirds of our lives, don't we?
No but she, she was like, awake and that and then she'd go "Oh, I'm going to bed" and then that'd be it for two days.
Talking of sleeping, oh man alive I went to see the last part of the Lord Of The Rings trilogy.
Well, it's like a family thing now, every, every Christmas my family and I have been going to see the Lord Of The Rings, the next installment. It's like a family thing.
What will you do if they keep making them?
Oh, I tell y-I've wasted now, about ten hours of my life for that tripe.
You can never get that back.
I can never get that back. That's what Peter Jackson owes me, ten hours now he owes me, of my life. It's absolute drivel.

We've said this before, I don't want to harp on again about it, but I cannot fathom why everyone is so excited and loves these films so much. Like you say, people, reviews saying it's the best film ever
"I think this is the greatest movie I'll ever see". And I don't-and it's like they go "Oh but look at all the fight sequences".
But Tolkien being there in literature like, you know what I mean? Sort of like "Shakespeare. Tolkien". No! No, no, no, no, no, no, no, no! No.
But what is it that he's writing about exactly?
Little midget fellas who can't get shoes.
One-I mean I've got big feet, I've got size fourteen, I can get shoes.
Send off for them, mail order.
But I know, it-it's-it is like, it's like er, Harry Potter taken seriously.
But I know who's watching it. It's like these people who are watching it are obviously nerds, people who live in Forbidden Planet, they love it, they can't believe their luck. It's like-
